fZe1MMeyhrlaIFXvnf3pJA.text: Visited February 2010. Sincerely, I don't have many confrontations, it's almost the first time that I eat in a traditional English elegant restaurant.Taking it into consideration, I loved it: the roast beef was simply perfect, so was also the Dover sole. In addition I tasted for the first time the Steak & Kidney Pie, whcih I also found interesting (and beautifully prepared).The place is old, traditional, looks like it has always been there. And service, lovely.We enjoyed a good New Zealand wine.A liittle bit pricey, but of course, it's London.

cFNUT86J2lZ9jVt1icAW4A.text: I have been to Simposons a number of times over the years. Let's not get wrapped up in nostalgia too much. The food is fine, it is not "Too die for" it's fine, it's ok, it's pretty consistant. Nothing more than that. The last time i went my partners liver came not pink, not rose not a little under done but damn well raw cold and jelly like. We then had to suffer a very patronising waiter try to convince me, "veals liver is meant to be that way sir" Bullshit! Thinly sliced pink no problems, thick (i mean very thick) slices cold and jelly like in the middle no. I chose (yet again) roast beef, well of course. It was fine.....not wow amazing it was fine. No one can deny the restaurant is quite special, in terms of structure of the room, decor etc. However, after that i seem to find it boring and clearly lacking a buzz, atmosphere, just something not quite right. Go to Simposns, please do, if you are a well expierienced "Dining out kinda person" don't (don't) expect to be blown away. I know restaurants, far, far, far better for quality of food. Simpsons not even in that race. Stand alone on food (Foreget the very special restaurant) i don't think Simpsons could cut it now, competing against the new breed of great class food, modern british restaurants. Simpsons is over priced, vastly over priced for the food. I guess if your happy to pay a lot of money to sit and look at the special restaurant fine, but i dont think you will see the value of your money on your plate. frankly if i had a lot of money to burn on looking at fine buildings i think i'd most likley keep it and spend it on a National trust membership ticket. See as many fine buildings as i like. All balanced up, same old story, living on ghosts in the corridors, the good old days and the like. Much has now gone. Over priced for average food. I don't think i'd waste my money and go again.

JbtVSlp1egnyP5SilAYWag.text: Been here with my girlfriend for Sunday Roast, and we both enjoyed our meal, I had the delicious roast beef.  Simpson's is an elegant dining experience.  Traditional roast carved at your table by the chefs who push the silver domed trolleys around the grand dining room.  There's a set menu for the roast from lunch until early evening, along with a regular menu.The dining experience may be pricey, but well worth a one time visit.  The grand dining room just adds an extra bit of flavor to your meal.

zgYXPrJSd-OuoEKT5CWnYw.text: Simpsons represents the pinnacle of traditional British food.  From the moment you first walk in and are greeted by the host, you feel as though you have stepped back in time to an older more refined period of time.  The staff are true professionals and make you feel special in everything that they do.  The building that it is located in used to be a private Chess club and there are mementos from that era sprinkled around the establishment.  As for the food, my favorite was the steak and kidney pudding, which is covered in a delicious and savory sauce.  For dessert, we had the spotted dick, which was fantastic.  This is a perfect place for a special dinner, or a romantic evening.

icFOBByzJFmaNglLb-qHxQ.text: Simpson's is a British Institution and whilst the price reflects this it is very reasonable when you consider the service, ambiance and quality of the food. This is comfort food at its finest, the roasts are ridiculously good. To the couple who arrived just as we were leaving, (thankfully), it is not OK to bring a baby here and it is not OK to wear jeans and t-shirts, sheesh!

vnXEIectxs343yg0wMV55A.text: A very formal restaurant in old English settings and not the most comfortable meal we have experienced. However, the food was exquisite. Starters of veal kidneys, which were fantastic, scallops with black pudding which were beautiful and the dressed crab that was fairly lifeless. Of course a visit to Simpson's would not be worthwhile without the roast beef and Yorkshire pudding. Simply gorgeous. Other mains on our table included the lamb, which was equally as good as the beef, the Wellington which was disappointing and an odd concoction of halibut with spiced lentils and vanilla cream sauce which seemed to work. All washed down with some over priced Rioja. The cheese board was wholly forgettable. Well worth a visit for the food and I guess the surroundings but lunch seems to offer a restaurant floor of whispering businessmen.

MovP2vZobCqQhn_JnayX9A.text: Good traditional style restaurant with great roast beef! I wouldn't say this was the best restaruant in the world as per ppxxtt above I am sure there are betterbut it is a great restaurant. The grand divan is so lovely - with wooden panelled walls. If you can get a booth, they are great - they seat about 4 - 6 people. We were just 2 but we sat in the middle of the restaurant and on a Saturday night it was so busy! The service was impeccable - such a change in this fastfood world we live in - and the beef was to die for! My only concern was the next table of guests. as my client and I ( it was a business dinner) went to leave and we were leaving a 1/3 of a bottle of wine ( we were both driving), the man on the next table leant across and rather rudely asked us to chuck over the bottle of wine, duck!!!I was so shockedand embarrassed - not the type of clientele you would expect at Simpsons! We did give in and handed over the bottle and then as we left, mentioned this to the maitre d' ( who had been excellent) and he then said he would charge them for the extra wine! Would love to have seen their faces when they came to get the bill!!

WgeXIaEKiLbacP7o1nz-QQ.text: beef wellington with mashed potatoes and roasted carrots! *drool*OMG . . over experience here is YUM!walking in, you might think this place is a bit stuffy because this place has been here for over 100+ years, but the staff is really helpful and really nice!as for the food . . of course i ordered the wellington w/mash . . :) - the sauce they poured on top of it was to die for.[for those that don't know or haven't had beef wellington, it takes a while to make -  so you have to remember to be patient for your food to come out, if you've ordered it!]prime rib is on my next to try list! - my friend got it and it looked delish!! - this place is like Lawry's style, carvers come up to the table and ask what cut you want etc . .  comes with side of roasted potatoes and greens . . & of course a yorkshire pudding . .my friends & i, then topped it off with a quad-try of desserts (dessert for 2) - man, though the wording of the dessert menu sounded strange, when it came out and we tasted it, there was nothing left on the plate at the end. . LOL. . it was perfect for the 3 of us - but it would have been just right with a 4th person . . make sure to make a reservation - even on a sunday, this place filled up pretty nicely . .dress attire = fancy (ish)cost = reasonable for what you're paying for . .drinks = loads of drinks to choose from, we got a bottle of wine to share and it went perfect with our food! BRING YOUR APPETITE!  - you might need to unbutton your pants after you're done eating here.

FwdQ5cDJ0I4MYptsXh4iDQ.text: Visited London and was told to try this place by my grandparents who had visited 40 years prior.  Very elegant and the service was impeccable.  Classic upscale British restaurant.  That night I had deer (for the first time in my life)  and it was very good.  This is definitely worth a stop on your trip.

H8E5QR9Vgj2Kqdfiyv9z3Q.text: Traditional English steakhouse, one of the oldest in London.

AlVB4ww4jc5a0uIc0vFc7Q.text: I regret taking 7 months to review this restaurant. On the first day I arrived in London back in June, 2012, I bought theater tickets for that night so I had to make sure I would make the curtain call.I had no idea where I was going to eat until I stumbled into this restaurant.Upon arrival, I made it known that I had theater ticket and wanted to be sure I would be served in a timely manner. The décor was traditional English--really beautiful--and the wait staff were very kind and accommodating and maybe more so since I dined alone.Since I was pressed for time, it was suggested I should order something from the carving station but I had my heart set on seafood.Lobster was the theme for me that night and to start, I had a lobster bisque--which to this day--is by far the best I've ever had in any city.For my main, I ordered the pan fried ocean trout which was prepared with a lobster sauce/mash & served with potatoes.The delicious white wine I ordered complemented my  meal perfectly.The delightful English waiters delivered on their promise to serve my meal promptly and I even  had time to spare.I loved this restaurant (it is quite pricey but worth it) , would recommend it to anyone and will revisit next time I"m in London.

b2J28Ur1vndqOIvec4ZiNQ.text: A classic London dining establishment that is not cheap, but well worth experiencing. They say its between the (roast) beef and lamb, which I completely agree with. Straying from what they do best always runs a small risk on quality, but sticking with the standards is likely not going to disappoint. I've been at least 3 or 4 times over the years & the service has always been excellent... so I'm a little skeptical of the knocks on that in other reviews.

vzrwMIzQYQcOwHdclXh18w.text: I was waiting for Consuelo Vanderbilt or the Duke of Westminster to come in when we ate here one Sunday for a traditional roast.Simpson's reminds one of a nineteenth-century gentlemen's club or the dining-room of a stately home when Britannia ruled the waves and the sun never set on the British Empire, when the P & O brought military personnel and civil servants back from the Colonies and the Raj was the brightest jewel in the crown.  All that aside, it's one of those places that you visit once to experience British "charm," which I believe doesn't exist outside of a Henry James or Evelyn Waugh novel, but I digress.The staff treat you like visiting royalty, from the person taking your coat, to the maitre 'd, to the wine steward, to the person pouring your water - there's about six people waiting on you.  First class service: what you expect from anything solidly British. We opted for the traditional Sunday roast, wheeled about on silver-domed trolleys, and started off with a lobster soup. The Sunday roast was served medium rare with horse-radish, Savoy cabbage (of course) and Yorkshire puddings.  Everything was impressive and delicious.  No one was dressed to the nines, but no one looked like slobs, either, so dress appropriately and at least look the part.

GlcwOoy3NMouA5HJ6A6K3w.text: It was a good traditional British dining experience. The atmosphere was really nice and so was the food. This restaurant is well known for its roasted beef and it was delicious, I recommend it.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Dining room.

jwUdu6HmPFVItJR81F5XoQ.text: Walking in, I was amazed at the beautiful interior, the coffered ceilings, the chandeliers and the wonderful pianist playing in the dining room. Loved the ambience. I felt like I was instantly transported back in time. Service was impeccable and the staff was very polite. I ordered the steamed sea bass w/ braised leeks, carrot, fennel, and lemon butter sauce and being that we were in London, my boyfriend had to order the beef wellington w/ roast salsify. Our waiter informed us that it would take approx. 25 mins to cook our food, but since we weren't starving, we didn't order appetizers to start. There was, of course, bread at the table, but it was very nice of them to bring us an amuse-bouche; a small cup of mushroom soup. It was very tasty and delicious! My steamed sea bass was done very well and had enough flavor that I feel the lemon butter sauce wasn't even needed. The beef wellington was also very good, but not quite the best we have had. The puff pastry was crisp, light and flaky however (as it should be). Our favorite will still be from One if by Land, Two if by Sea in NYC.

nn5f321OILde8JmbS2_lQw.text: Visited October 2008. This was a must visit restaurant of my wife. I loved it too. We had good waiting staff. As it was a belated wedding anniversary gift to ourselves; my son had arranged a bottle of champagne for our arrival. (NOTE: Had already had two bottles when we had visit the show at Her Majesty's Theatre). The waiter said that we probably would need the wine menu. I said that he clearly didn't know us, especially as he offered water to us too. Hence ordering a very nice Australian Shiraz to got with the equally excellent beef. Everyone has written about similar food at the restaurant, and we couldn't find a fault. We selected the option of several dessert tasters. They were all fantastic. Claridges is next on my wife's list of places to visit. This is burning a hole in the mortgage.

SmlFa4RSGLTFQUdx_HgV0A.text: This has been a London institution since 1828. The vast dining room, with its dark wood trim, crystal chandeliers, and gold-toned ceiling, looks like the setting for a film set in the 1930s, and the service is impeccable.To start we shared an order of duck liver pate with mulled pears. For our entrees, we ordered two of their signature dishes, roast rib of beef and roast saddle of lamb. Both were served with roast potatoes and cabbage, and the beef was accompanied by Yorkshire pudding as well. For dessert we had the pudding sampler, which is designed for two people to share.Everything was well-prepared and tasty, but nothing was extraordinary, which it should be when you're paying £85 for lunch.There's a three-course fixed price menu for £29.50 served until 7.00pm, although if you order the roast beef for which they're known, you'll pay a £6.00 supplement. Considering how limited the options for each course are, the slight savings probably isn't worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom

VbPXDUVwB6wvRuceXLz6OA.text: We've only been eating here for 32 years.  We've eaten in all the rooms. We've had fish, meat and love the bar and champagne upstairs.It's staid, pricey and good.  We've been going for 32 years. You should go for 32 years.

Y594wUOinPR3V8IG33r0gw.text: Everything was perfect, from the oysters on ice to start to the piano being played in the corner. To the sommeliers personal recommendations. Just pure old school quality English establishment is how I class the eatery. Would recommend it to anyone.

iOnUEd2urySTW8BwmcCBgA.text: Went for Sunday lunch with the in-laws.Staff were pleasant and helpful - they took a family picture for us in one of the private dinining rooms which was very nice, and made it easy to go with kids.The dining room was losing the fight against the cold outside, we were all sat cold with jumpers on, and the food wasn't much better. Yes the roast beef is nice but it's no better than any half decent gastropub and although the carving at the table is nice the magic has long gone.You can imagine how this place must have been; but on a cold Sunday, empty apart from 3-4 tables of tourists it's really very sad.

l3wa-n-z70QsauUKCxrTcw.text: Very British Traditional. From wood-paneled walls to old, deep-sinking cushioned seats, you get a real feel for what it was like back-in-the-day (also expensive for what it is). Evenings include a live pianist playing unobtrusively in the background, providing a very formal dining experience for guests.We love the Beef Wellington here. It's always perfectly done, and takes a bit longer to come out, but I always find myself dipping my fork into my fiance's plate for another small piece.And of course, the large, rolling trays of huge beef roasts, being heated by gas canisters, carved tableside by master carvers wearing tall white hats, and large dollops of house-made horseradish sauce on the side. Did anybody mention that it's only a few GBPs (last I went, GBP5) for seconds??Yessir, I'd pay for this again! Especially since they say formal attire and I always wear sneakers and jeans every time!

1fLnMlfnYUn7SprvnIzO9A.text: In terms of classic British cuisine, Simpsons in the Strand is definitely among the elite. If you're a beef lover then order nothing else other than their infamous roast beef. It is absolutely glorious and represents everything a perfect roast beef should be. Try it and you will not disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom

0ewb6fWP32sMZzoh2hx6Jg.text: The food is excellent quality and well prepared although quite buttery. Tonight the service was very slow taking 25 minutes before we had water at the table and over 2 hours to serve the entree.

EEMySKSMI4jhZrPPmy3yMw.text: This was recommended by the hotel I stayed at.  It was a good exposure to classic British haute cuisine...a veritable oxymoron, but they were VERY accomodating to our party.  We spent a lot of £ so I'm sure that helped.  While the food isn't amazing it's solid, well presented and uses a lot if fresh ingredients.  The Yorkshire pudding in itself is a masterpiece.  The new culinary trend in the UK makes Simpsons look like King George era, but it's solid like I said.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. English Pea Risotto

YETEyWBrhb4P9s3hg8z3dg.text: One word: GROSS. We had 6 guests dine and all were thoroughly disappointed. The lamb was overcooked and inedible. One diner ordered chicken and received steak. The scallops were also overcooked and just disguising. DO NOT EAT HERE and waste your money. Oh and it was $200 per person!

oc-7SbOrhdus39SakCB1yw.text: Simpsons was always one of those places I had on a 'tick list' of places to go but I hadn't expected to do it so informally. Having been to various London sights, we needed to eat before seeing All My Sons and our friends had been there before and recommended it. We phoned and booked a table for 4 people at 5pm - the first sitting on a Saturday which suited us absoutely (I'd never eat that early normally). Arriving before our chaps, we went to the bar upstairs for a G&T. Lovely plump sofas and chairs to sink into and relax; the fact that we were dressed for comfort rather than style was not an issue as I had feared - probably a 'girl' thing. We went to our table just after 5pm and were not the first in the restaurant. The pianist was already playing and there was a long table for a party of about 25 people already placing their orders. Service was super. The guys ordered starters and we girls received a complimentary amuse bouche (sp?) at the same time which was very thoughtful. One of our group had the roast beef and there was loads of it with all the trimmings - a very generous meal with the option of 'seconds' for a small additional fee. All the food was really good, served well and really fresh. The chap on the after dinner drinks trolley is fab! Really passionate about his stuff and very happy to share his expertise and experience - almost a floor show in himself. Having been, I'd be more than happy to continue ticking other places off my list before going back but I'm sure we'll return.

nCKBaHAbsfZU0JUGvK5uFw.text: My boyfriend took me here for a congratulations-on-your-new-job dinner. It did the job wonderfully. A bit like being in Mary Poppins thanks to its venerable heritage (there are little fact boards dotted around the foyer) and plethora of aged men working there, it was a real experience. We had a drink in the knights bar (or whatever it's called upstairs first). Bloke's martini came in what looked like a wine glass which he wasn't very partial to and apparently not the best martini he's had. I enjoyed my amaretto sour and would quite have liked another one, but the barman kept on disappearing. Good thing we weren't in a hurry. The dining room was superb though. We had a lovely booth to ourselves, the staff were just the right side of intelligent but butler-ish and the food was incredible. I had the roast, silver platter and all. We shared a half bottle of some pretty phenomenal red and didn't bother with starter or pudding due to the vast quantities of meat we were having. It was pretty terrific meat. Yum. A really memorable meal, stunning room, just don't bother with the bar unless you have a whip or something to stir the barstaff into action.

DPjSlUnBROhv0wthw5JcrQ.text: Didn't know anything about the place before I went, but absolutely loved it. Had calves liver which is one of my favourite dishes and thought it was gorgeous. My mouth is watering just thinking about it and it's weeks since my trip. The ceremony of the meat carving is fun, a doddery chap wheeled up the meat trolley and carved my tiny lithe friend an enormous slab of meat and added a yorkshire pudding bigger than her head to the plate. No small portions here. The only thing I didn't like is that my main was so big I had no room for pudding and pudding is always the best bit of any meal.

hjvTeT8qL9s6PaUQx2oh2w.text: This is as traditional and historic restaurant as there is..roast beef and Yorkshire pudding is worth the experience...generous portions, attentive staff, fine dining and not any question that it is worth the price.  Not touristy, just classy!

DSTBgiPp93oNZ4iUg6QNug.text: I don't recommend this place. It was way too hot and stuffy in there, felt like a sauna. Their windows do not open and they do not have AC. Their servers have to wear full suits, so they smell like sweat (I don't blame them, they are required to dress like that). It was hotter than outside. It was so stuffy that it was nearly impossible to enjoy the food.The bottle of wine came very warm - yuck! Do they lack refrigerators too perhaps?? The food was very mediocre. The bread that comes with their steak was pretty good. The beef was just OK, nothing special. The duck breast was very mediocre, the skin very chewy. The duck confit meatball was very tasty. The piano music is nice. The building itself is beautiful, but too bad they lack proper air circulation. Overall, bad experience. We regretted wasting a dinner in London at this place. Don't waste your time here, much better places in London.

ZXFS3WqhgMgQeN9H38JyZA.text: A beautifully elegant British dining experience. This is how I imagine old world posh London was.We went as the finale of our own Sherlock Holmes walking tour (Sherlock's favourite restaurant don't you know?) and it was a lovely way to end the day.We were slightly early for our table so we treated ourselves to cocktails in the bar. It's not cheap at £12.50 per cocktail but they were delicious.The bar was pretty empty though so lacked atmosphere. The restaurant is beautiful and we were treated so kindly by all who served us, without it being pompous.We had gorgeous fish starters; me baked crab which was divine and my date smoked salmon which he said was delicious.We then opted for the signature of the restaurant, the roast beef.It's carved by your table on a huge silver tray, and you can opt for how you'd like your meat still.The portion size was good, the beef accompanied by a huge Yorkshire pudding, a dollop of very tasty horseradish (and I've never liked horseradish before!), roast potatoes and Savoy cabbage.The beef was tender and flavour some. Whilst we ate we listened to the delightful piano playing and people watched as the restaurant filled with an array of diners.It was a very enjoyable experience to eat  at such a British institution of a restaurant and have such yummy food.It's certainly not cheap, but it's worth it for a special occasion.Sherlock Holmes definitely had good taste!

xg2ePF_1_JtwKcWydwwNvw.text: We had the most beautiful amazing wonderful meal.  Still dreaming about the pea and leek tart, Dover sole..and the piano music made us feel like we were having a private romantic concert. Service was exceptional, food superb!!  Can't wait to return.. highly recommend this restaurant, a delightful evening!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom

5PhIn7O7NIP4FOwCN6zFOA.text: We were guests at the Savoy adjacent to Simpsons. Over the course of our stay we ate breakfast daily and dinner one evening. We have been frequenting Simpsons each and every trip to London and have never been disappointed. The main room has a historical presence and the meal always a treat.

bDnRLpQtrMmJxfNr02yANQ.text: Took my mum here for Mother's Day and we had the Pre Theatre menu which was still very full of wonderful choices unlike other places. The venue is like eating in a museum. This unassuming gem in the heart of London with character pouring down the walls is an amazing place to treat someone. The food is exceptional. The service is wonderful, the staff all seem very proud to work there as would I if I worked there.

VWBR7DizPevF62CXp8kL0g.text: Very cool old school British atmosphere. We were the only customers under 60 in the entire place. The carved beef was good as was the horseradish but nothing fantastic. The service was very slow and they weren't busy. It took 30 minutes just to get a drink. Not very impressive - don't waste your  time or money.

hkNVnL1Tl0IiIMUpUoSnZg.text: King Me ImpressedLocated in the posh and historic Savoy building in what once was an opulent chess room, this fine dining restaurant lives up to its grand reputation. Elegantly appointed tables with crisp white linens, wait staff in formal black suits, and even a grand piano with an exceptionally talented pianist, create the perfect ambiance for a memorable evening. The menu is traditional and a bit of a step into the past with classic fare from local game and steaks to fresh wild caught fish. As a starter I enjoyed the Salmon Tartar.  A beautifully presented medallion of marinated smoked salmon topped with creme fraiche and caviar on a bed of crisp paper thin cucumber slices. While it sounds simple, it was so perfectly dressed that it danced with fresh flavor and finish. One of the best I've ever had. For my main, I had to choose the Lamb Saddle carved table-side on a grand trolley, the likes of which I haven't seen in decades.  The Chef was a master with a blade that seemed to melt the perfectly roasted meat which was then delicately placed on my plate with a flourish of red currant jelly and a dash of house made mint sauce. Accompanied by twice cooked crisp potatoes and rocket with Stilton dress, this dish prompted thoughts of grander Victorian times when dining was truly a proper experience.  Lovely, and actually a bit romantic, with the setting and ambiance of the melodic background piano medleys. We finished with a desert tasting that included treacle, lemon square, chocolate mousse and ice cream trio. All delightful. What a wonderful way to make any evening a special occasion.

hbJJEDORRJoYoeZcHA3Rag.text: It was our last night together in London and my fiance wanted to get me beef wellington on Sunday around 7pm. Not an easy task since most places close early. I was hesitant to go here because I felt I was not dressed but since it was raining and cold, everyone was wearing jeans and a sweater. It was so interesting to see a lot of people get the roast. It certainly is a sight to behold the chef carving it before you. I had the beef wellington and it was absolutely remarkable from the flaky outside to the demi glacé sauce. If I weren't in the presence of others, I would have licked my plate. The portion was on par with having had an appetizer. We also had the scallop appetizer because the welly would take 35 min. I'm not sure what the sauce was, maybe beurre blanc. The scallop was lightly fried. I'm sure there were loads of butter in it but it tasted absolutely divine! We skipped dessert since I couldn't keep my eyes open from so much touring. The ambience was romantic and elegant. I really would have loved to come here in something better than jeans, sweater and sneakers but c'est la vie. This isn't the kind of thing we'd have daily since it tastes too rich with all the butter but it is fabulous to have once a week or so. I'd love to come here several times on our next visit.

Eo3_Z8vuD_R6jZQF0l47hw.text: I was given a very thoughtful gift from my parents of a carving course at Simpson's, which was a morning of teaching followed by carving roast for your guests at Sunday lunch. My dad did the course about 15 years ago and loved it so it was a really sweet gesture.Unfortunately, things have changed in 15 years. When I was having lunch after, my dad wanted to go over techniques and tricks and it turned out I'd learned barely anything - it has obviously been simplified a lot, and even as I was being taught I was surprised at the lack of detail and even though I don't consider myself to be at all skilled, it did seem like the lesson could have been summed up in 10 minutes. I thought maybe this was just how things are in carving but the fact that my dad was able to talk much more about different appropriate knives and the grain of the meat showed me that I had had a much less rigorous experience. This could also be because there were about 20-25 people at my lesson, whereas my dad was with 8. The cynic in me thinks this has just become a bit of a money spinner.To be honest, though, I would probably have settled for this and been happy enough with a pleasant morning of meat, were it not for two other factors.Firstly, I could neither believe nor stand the casual and continual sexism coming from the so-called master cook. The class was very imbalanced, with only 3 women, and I suspect this is often the case, but we might as well not have been there. The cook addressed us as if we were all men and kept up incessant patter that started off in the world of tired mother-in-law jokes but soon strayed into the more generalised and offensive commentary about how women are bad at cooking (even though the kitchen is our domain) and the suggestions that we are mainly around for the cleaning and the drudge work. It was abhorrent. He would look right through me as he chummily referred to how our wives always overcook meat and nag us to do things too quickly. I felt like I was about a century earlier - which may not be the traditional flavour a top end restaurant should aspire to. Seriously, it made me very uncomfortable and put me on edge, which considering that it's a fairly luxury activity, should never have been allowed to happen.Secondly, it was just poorly organised. This was apparent in the run up, where at different points I had both the wrong date and the wrong number of guests confirmed. But it was also clear on the day. At one point, people were asked to order drinks - which they did, and then were immediately given a complimentary glass of wine, followed by the wine they had just ordered. And frustratingly for me, the class finished at 12:30, while my lunch seating was at 13:45. Now, I understand not everyone can be seated at once, but why wasn't it clear in the details that it would finish earlier? My guests were only arriving for lunch, whereas had I known I would have invited them earlier for a pre-meal drink. Thus I was left along to awkwardly hover and wait for an hour.Obviously, for most of you, you're really only interested in the review of the meal. It's a bit mixed. The meat was certainly delicious (beef or lamb are the best); everything else I had was a bit meh. But the service was truly appalling. We were overcrowded by far too many waiters, but none of them seemed to have been doing the job for more than a few hours. We kept being asked things we had already been asked, we had people lean over us to pass plates along, and there was a particularly odd moment when a man insisted that he was giving my boyfriend his treacle sponge when he was really passing him my chocolate mousse - he evidently didn't know what either looked like. Oh, and my dad was continually addressed as if he was the carver (I mean, he's the man, right, so that makes sense), so we kept having to awkwardly correct them.To finish with, I was presented with a certificate - which I had to point out had a smear of gravy on it.Low, low level of customer service that is particularly infuriating at an establishment that regards itself so highly. Go anywhere else.

cSTQiuZhZFwOzR90KMqpqw.text: I first went here 20 years ago on my first trip to London, and went back because I loved it then.  I was not disappointed this time.  My wife had her favorite dish in the whole world, beef wellington, and said it was the best she has ever had, and I had to have the carved roast beef, so good!  Old classic and cool!

Jfp7Ydi61nhM5W9k_-OSoQ.text: I read that Charles Darwin and Benjamin Disreali enjoyed frequenting Simpsons in their day.  The meal is traditional British and not much has changed since the mid 19th century.  The establishment sticks to its British roots with the focus on the 28 day aged scottish beef roast.  A chef wheels out a huge rib roast on a cart and carves you slices right then and there.  Paired with yorkshire pudding, savoy cabbage and roasted potatoes it is the most classic meal in London.  The rest of the "bill of fare" is decked out with a dose of Beef Wellington, venison, roasted leg of partridge, liver and dover sole.If you like english roasts or want to pretend you are a 19th century gentleman, definitely stop by Simpsons.  Go to the American Bar in the Savoy for a nightcap.

AdY1xQ1644Uqk2HCeNUyUw.text: Classic London dining experience that must be ventured at least once in your life.  I've been twice now, about 20 years apart and enjoyed both occasions.   Both featured the signature beef and Pudding.  Ambiance remains a walk back in time to headier days of the empire.  It must be said that the latest visit featured a significantly smaller portion of beef.  Also the table side carving service seemed a bit rushed, despite the smallish weekend patronage.   Overall very enjoyable for an every 20 year experience.

ZVHKIMqWyOJZUsFF8ajlTA.text: A beautiful and classic British restaurant located just opposite of the famous Savoy theatre - perfect for a pre theatre dinner. The place holds a great deal of history as it was originally opened in 1828 as a chess club and coffee house. The service was impeccable and the dining room is very charming. We all ordered one of the signature dishes "Roast rib of Scottish beef (aged 28 days)" with Roast potatoes, Savoy cabbage, Yorkshire pudding & horseradish. We were very pleased with the taste, but even better was that they roll the huge piece of beef out in a trolly and make a show of the carving process. I very much enjoyed that and the food was very good too, especially the horseradish. I gladly recommend!

J_TXspNunoILlwbnEnzUnQ.text: Wonderful wood paneled main room. Silver dishes of roast beef carved at the table circulating the dinning room silently. This is still lovely after over a century...nothing says Brit more than this place. The ox tail soup was perfect, fresh made, unsalty, earthy taste. A must for us tourists who are well treated and respected by the excellent wait staff.

LhOlC6xDZJfcc8BfAtO5zQ.text: If you are going to go for tradition, this is the place to go.I went to this place as it is a very historical and popular place.  Be warned, that the English fare these days in UK and in pubs are great, ever since the breweries took over contol of the pubs.  The pub owners had to open up the restaurant parts of their pubs to generate more income and profit.1.  Ambiance - Traditional English. You  have to go to this place to be part of the tradition.2.  Service - I found it to be a bit old fashion, but certainly very professional. I believe traditional is more the word.3.  Food - I order the roast rib of beef with all the trimmings and yorkshire pudding. I loved everything, except for the fact that I could not get the rib cooked the temperature that I wanted it. I like it medium rare to rare and the waiter advised me that they were serving it medium.I will go back because I love British food, I want to try their steak and kidney pie, braised lamb shank. and I am excited to try their Oxtail Faggot as a starter. I know, it sound different, if you are not from the UK.GK says, ya gotta go to check this place out for sure.

TgRDZekVDdw12WUtjECgGw.text: This is one of the quintessential old english eateries, founded in 1828 and located on the Strand adjacent to the famous Savoy hotel. Charles Dickens and Vincent Van Gogh (not a typo) sampled fare here historically. It is the second oldest continuous operating restaurant in London ( "Rules" being the oldest). Food is served in a classic wood dining room lit by majestic chandeliers, with somewhat annoying piano music being played.   Numerous waiters and carvers whisk silver metal domed trolleys full of roast legs of lamb and rib roasts for table side carvery.  Truly a roll back on how the aristrocratic elite dined 100 years ago. (Ironically, i was dressed in a sports coat and collared shirt and was amply dressed up). The ambiance was thoroughly enjoyable. This aspect of the restaurant is why you go to eat at Simpson In the Strand, as the food  was good, but nothing spectacular, especially for the price.Before we were seated for our 6:30 pm reservation, we had drinks up at the Simpson tavern first (upstairs) after the maitre'd was kind enough to ask if we preferred to start our meal with a drink , which we did. Four of us, each ordered an unmemorable drink for about £8 ( $12 USD), prior to dinner.  The seating was comfortable and intimate.For starters (appetizer), I sampled the roast wood pigeon breast with bacon. The meat was cooked a little rare for my liking and even at that it was a bit tough. It consisted of about 3 small bites. Two in our party had the fish cake with chive butter sauce, which was delightful. The other starter a rabbit and crayfish tart was nicely presented in between 2 pastries, but was devoid of shrimp and the flavors didn't seem to mix. We ordered a bottle of NZ white semillon ( £42/$65USD) with our meal.For main course, I ordered the whole dover sole (£35/$54 USD), which was grilled in lemon butter. The sole was fresh and cooked to perfection. It was of ample size and the skin was removed.  Anyone who likes fish and has never had whole dover sole, you must try it. One of us ordered the roast ribeye (prime rib) accompanied with a yorkshire pudding, roast potatos and savoy cabbage. The meat was sliced table side thinly, not akin to American prime rib, which is served as a tender thick sliced ribeye....this was a bit disappointing, but the portion was adequate, with the starters ordered. The beef wellington was superb served a nice medium, but the fourth meal we ordered, a pan roasted leg of partridge, was disappointing. The partridge was tough. We also ordered shared sides of honey roasted parsnips, cauliflower cheese with bacon, the seasonal greens chile style ( broccolini), along with an order of mash potatos. All sides were superb and nicely presented in copper ramekins.For dessert and apertifs,  we ordered a cheese plate, 2 person pudding sampler, one house port, and one glass of house red wine. All were unimpressive. We finished our meal with coffees and a pot of tea. Dinner for four with 1 bottle of wine was £380 or about $580 USD. The ambience at Simpson's is superb and the service attentive, but the food unimpressive. Go there for the historical experience.

ykHjKUN163zA1qE5ox3cBA.text: So incredibly impressed I am with Simpsons in the Strand. A lovely group of 9 of my friends and I dined at Simpons in the Strand to celebrate a very special birthday last night, and I have not yet stopped thinking about our exquisite meal and exciting and stimulating conversations. It was one of the most amazing dinners I have ever attended, and a large amount of credit is due to Simpons' for this. Walking in, you automatically feel first-class as someone takes your name and another immediately grabs your coat. You watch as other extremely posh people walk in, and you just can't stop admiring them. Simpons' boasts an older crowd with the majority of people aged 50++, most decked in fur coats and dripping in jewels and diamonds. You start to wonder if you are in the right place as you check your outfit and the birth date on your I.D. Once you realize that although you don't exactly fit in, you also realize that you damn well deserve to be there because you are so fabulous in your own right. You strut to the table, sit down on the chair held out for you, and say thank you to the server for placing the napkin on your lap, pouring your water, and placing bread and butter on the table before you can even set your purse down. As we all embraced the comfort of our circle of friends and fill each other in on the latest scoop, we load up on butter and bread... but mainly butter. they start us off with a small cup of creamy soup and then the food comes out, altogether, which makes all the difference to me. I look down at my plate, and I immediately get aroused. I look to my right, left, and across the table and realize that everyone's dish looks outstanding. We begin to eat, rave about our food, and proceed to pass small bites of our own dishes across the table for everyone to taste. Combined, our table ordered the stuffed pork tenderloin, the roast beef, the lamb, and the beef wellington. Everything - I mean everything - was extremely moist and flavorful. Although everything was noteworthy, there were some dishes better than the rest. I'm not a wishy-washy person and I can always choose something over another, which is why I'll tell you now which dishes you cannot leave without trying. Please please please do yourself a favor and order the roast saddle of lamb and the beef wellington. They are incredibly thoughtful and delicious dishes, and they will inspire you.4-6 bottles of wine and an assortment of desserts later, we leave fully satisfied and the birthday boy is in bliss.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Roast Beef.
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Stuffed Pork Tenderloin.
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Roast Saddle of Lamb with the jam that compliments it so well.

3NPL1Xc3mdB_FLciPP80Vw.text: Food was great, service was attentive and the atmosphere was superb !  Truly elegant British dining experience.  Start with a drink in the bar upstairs.  You will have a enjoyable evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Great British experience !

5akTf1YnIm01-YWMSJnnNg.text: Marvellous traditional British restaurant in the heart of London. We enjoyed the meal, service and atmosphere.

DQnMK7Da6BFi0saUTz2Sfw.text: Classic British food done well with above average service.The atmosphere is traditionally English and the staff are very well trained and mannered.  The food was good, the roast beef was excellent, as was the lamb.  If you even moderately like roast beef, you should give Simpson's In The Strand a try and see how roast beef tastes when done correctly.Certainly not the best dining experience I've ever had and definitely not a notable one; however, it was pleasant and above average.

dL4dOTAYmbTg4OwEvNHN1Q.text: Ah, Simpson's!  I've been dining here off and on for perhaps 30 years, and keep coming back.  The food - traditional English - is perfect (the horseradish sauce is the world's best!).I lunched here with five friends in April, and I have one small niggle: the piano is too loud and makes conversation at a larger table difficult for older ears (4 or us were "of a certain age"), and when the pianist sang, it became almost impossible.Dear Simpson's: keep doing what you do so well, but please do something to bring back the quieter experience I remember so fondly!

phkvWvLUPSbYfUJmBljGoA.text: Spent the week in London, and sought out the best roast beef dinner in Town. After reading reviews, we came here for lunch. It's all my husband wanted on this trip! Simpson's did not disappoint him! I do wish the website encouraged "nice" dress even if jacket not required. We had on jeans and sweatshirts due to weather and I felt very underdressed in the stunning, old setting. We were told this was the second oldest restaurant in London. Spectacular room! The food is fresh and delicious! The roast beef was cooked to perfection. His only complaint was he got full! One small incident was corrected quickly without any hesitation. Wonderful service! Highly recommend! (And wear the nice clothes you brought! )

h8zS8PEaHaTA8W3kIK3lQg.text: I first dined at Simpson's November 2015. I was in London - with a friend born and raised in the city - so why wouldn't I want to try the best place serving Roast beef and Yorkshire pudding. Simpson's. Just for a bit of history - I'm a huge fan of Roast Beef, Yorkshire pudding and the fixings. Growing up we had an awesome babysitter who came from London. She didn't have any children and we became her surrogate kids. On occasion she would make dinner for us. And when she did she would make this traditional British meal. So I grew up with a proper Roast Beef and Yorkshire pudding meal. In fact - as an adult - I make this meal myself for Holidays and special occasions. I use my babysitters recipe and it is consistently awesome!!!!  My kids love it. So I am a tough customer when it comes to this meal. When we visited Simpson's the first time in November of 2015 I was really impressed. They walked around the restaurant with a carving station so you could get the perfect slice of beef!  The restaurant is very old school and exactly what you would expect from a local spot specializing in this meal. Staff super friendly and accommodating. We revisited Simpson's last month. After a 6 month renovation. They have maintained all the goodness. In particular the sides are fantastic. Roasted potatoes and fries are stellar. Mac n' Cheese and many other apps fantastic!  The only criticism I have is the Yorkshire Pudding. It's fine but not what I'm used to or how I make it. My Yorkshire Pudding is golden and crispy on the outside and edges but actually moist and pudding like on the center. Simpson's is very crusty, dark brown and fairly dry. Good. But not - to me a traditional Yorkshire Pudding. I asked the waiter for a less cooked piece and he said that a 'proper' Yorkshire Pudding is cooked well and dark and crusty.....  I prefer the way I make it!Either way. We will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom

FRvmLacvUE2jdOb6yuta9A.text: My fiancé and I went here for dinner on our last night in London and I'm so pleased that we did! He wanted a traditional welsh dinner which is typically served on Sunday, but we weren't in London on Sunday and Simpson's was one of only a few who have a traditional roast beef meal during the week.They have a carving station that is cut table side. I ordered the welsh lamb and he ordered the roast beef. The portions are perfect, they cover the plate entirely with meat, for me lamb with mint sauce and gravy. For my fiancé roast beef and gravy. The sides are then served, which were wonderful. With my lamb I had potatoes o gratin and green beans. For the roast beef, he had carrots and the biggest piece of Yorkshire pudding we've ever seen.We were too full for dessert but they brought out a small dessert for us anyway. Apricot jelly cubes, after 8 mints and fudge. The atmosphere was wonderful and so was the service and food! When I return to London, I'll be sure to go back! Make sure to make a reservation as they are quite busy!

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Side of carrots and Yorkshire pudding
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Traditional roast beef off the carving cart
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom. Side of green beans and potatoes

6roRqogqvEuXUx20xbXaeg.text: Took my mother here for dinner on our first night in London as a surprise. Unknowingly, my mother loves this place since my father took her here 20-something years ago. The roast beef and yorkshire was amazing. Took me back to when my nan used to make it. My mother loved her fish. Our server Roy (?) was extremely nice, knowledgable and attentive. Will try to get back there some day.

QgG7zVNsWYv5hEdFbi0Q1g.text: What could go wrong with a 180 year old establishment serving prime rib?  Nothing. It was perfect!

cDWtzi_2aoaYRJs02FrvqQ.text: Hello there.Not much to say. A true english classic. No words to describe but one needs to experience it themselves. Proper english feast. The plates were served well. Properly timed ! Scallops with squid ink :) . I had pigeon which was kind of rare but the meat was tender and sides accompanied it well to a point where i was surprised.  The roasted beef and Yorkshire pudding with gravy was just marvelous. Roasted potato with duck fat & peas Fit for a king kinda of night. The fare definitely shines a proper feast fit for a king. Its an experience one will remember for a lifetime. I would recommend anyone in a heart beat.Good atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom

ejG8wHuLe7jHG-suRRncZQ.text: Just a tremendous dining experience. Food great, wine pairing great, service great...the Beef Wellington OMG! ...all you'd expect of a premium restaurant. Very little much more to say. It lives up to its prices, you'll enjoy!

yHJUM8BIya3mhQhWy5Q-yw.text: I started with a drink in the 1st floor bar. The barman, Harry, was very friendly, and the OMG drink, based on Churchill, really set the tone for the evening. Downstairs, in the dining room, Roy was very helpful in getting what I wanted, how I wanted it. At the end of the meal, he rang ahead to the American Bar, and had them save me a table. All in all, a fantastic restauraunt, and fantastic staff!

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom

qEasgTzM-vXx-F5z40SAPQ.text: Wonderful for a special occasion - but priceySimpson's never disappoints...The wine selection is almost endless. The Silver Trolley with the 28 day dry-aged roast rib of Scottish beef was cooked and served to perfection. Whenever we go to Simpson's, we always order the Treacle pudding...but, alas, it had been taken off the menu just a few weeks prior to our dining.When we told them about it, they said next time you come, give us a day of notice and we will make it for you.Talk about customer Service!

OS3gNsRiohDsp6oG-F9DFg.text: It's a nice experience to have Sunday roast here where they have an elegant dining room and meat being wheeled around for carving tableside. That said, the food itself was rather unremarkable. I found the rib roast tender but lacking a lot of flavor (the gravy and horseradish helps a lot). The vegetables were well salted but also lacking any real inspiration or triumph over mediocrity.The service was great. Overall, it isn't a great deal price wise for the food but the entire experience taken together makes it okay and worth going as an experience.

MFqvDh6zRhQtjIzPPJK2Lw.text: I'm giving five stars because they were extremely accommodating about any mistakes. I ordered the sirloin and asked for rare (I like my steak nearly blue) and it came out medium. They immediately rectified the situation by fixing the order and offering a free slice of their famous roast beef with all the works. The roast beef was wonderful! To add, they even comped the dessert because of what happened. My friend ordered the beef Wellington and she loved it. Would definitely return in the future, but probably will order the roast beef over the steaks.

HQ5F6uI_6AmyLzoB7plcWQ.text: We went for a date night and had an overall good experience. We first grabbed a few drinks at the bar upstairs. They had a great menu of gin-based cocktails. I absolutely loved my fruity one, although it did cost £16ish. Bar area wasn't too big or posh, but just the right balance of classy yet down to earth. We then moved downstairs for dinner. I had shrimps on toast for starter then mussels for main. I must admit, their seafood dishes weren't the best I had. Some of the mussels weren't very fresh, and I thought the base broth could have been better. Next time, I think I'll try more of the red meat dishes. Obviously, that's what this place is known for anyway. Service was overall solid. They promptly topped up our water glasses throughout the dinner and had a great friendly attitude. Ambience was excellent. Quintessentially British and posh, but not overly done. Would love to go back to try out more of their dishes.

mxKAyG5r8oW9gSKl8CrPBw.text: I always enjoy going to Simpson's In the Strand for a traditional roast and the experience when I'm in London with my parents.  The roast has always been spectacular.  The Yorkshire pudding is also very good.  I like the side creamed spinach as well (additional charge).  I'm not a fan of potatoes or cabbage, so those included sides were wasted on me.  The service came in waves of timing.  It went from quick to very slow by the end of our dinner.If you want a very traditional dinner in a upscale location, visit here.  However, a lot of pubs have just as good food.As a side note as regarding the noise level.  Our booth was quite pleasant for quiet conversation, but when we had questions about the menu or tried to order all the waiters had trouble hearing and saying how noisy it was for them.

aft3VlRaSY38pN5URdd5ew.text: Charmingly dated, Simpson's is about as "classic London" as you can get, and I hope it never changes. There is something magical about walking into a dining room that once served Charles Dickens and hasn't changed much since.While the menu is pricey, they are offering a Groupon which is an amazing deal: two courses per person and wine for £39 total. Your mains are either the roast beef or lamb, but considering the a la carte prices for each of those mains is over £30 each, you realize what a tremendous bargain this deal is. The food was very good, and very classic British. The roast beef was tender, and the sides of cabbage, potatoes, and Yorkshire pudding were all done nicely. There is something so neat about being served tableside from a silver trolley. We chose desserts instead of starters for our second course, and thought they were lovely. My treacle sponge was easily one of the best desserts I had while touring the UK, and the sticky toffee pudding was quite nice was well.Service was pretty good. The staff were warm, welcoming, and attentive. Our server was a little slow (sides coming a few minutes after the mains, slow to bring pepper, etc.), but he was very nice. I would definitely dress nicely to come here. I wore nice wool trousers and a button down shirt and felt quite comfortable, but you could be equally comfortable in a suit and tie if you wanted. The only person I saw wearing jeans was a tacky American who was eating his Yorkshire with his hands like it was a baguette.

BSyMZela4ttJcPIPZkoqMg.text: Three stars, that got you looking. The room is classic. It is the classic restaurant serving the Sunday joint done up fancy. However, compared to the modern incarnations in the States like Lawrys and The Prime Rib, it pales in comparison. Live piano music in the background. The music was the right volume and tempo, but it was odd to hear "House of the Rising Sun" being played.Service was generally excellent, although they had trouble keeping water in the glass. At the price point, and the length of time they've been doing things, it should be perfect. Perhaps it was perfect in the 50's and 60's, but it doesn't match what others are doing. It doesn't really seem to matter how you ask for the prime rib, they just slice it off the end they are working from. I asked for rare. I always ask for that knowing it's going to be medium rare, but it gives them the hint I want the meat from the middle, not the ends where it's more cooked. Unfortunately, I hit them when they were working from the end on a new piece. Indeed when they got to another table later asking for medium, they got the medium rare from the middle since that's where they were at.The horseradish isn't very good. The yorkshire pudding and roasted potatoes were very good. The cabbage, OK. All in all, OK food at best for the price. Good service. A spectacular room.

photos.caption: Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Simpson's in the Strand - London, United Kingdom

8-P8IbWsxz7Yh_CZiu9NiQ.text: Based on reviews of friends and what we've read on Yelp we were looking forward to our dinner at Simpsons.  This restaurant has definite strengths as supported by other reviews. But, our daughter was served a rancid (and i mean rancid as in "reeked of freaking putridness" rancid) flank steak that has spoiled our opinion.  The server quickly replaced her meal and explained that the chef said the 45 day aging of the meat can create a smell that some people are not accustomed to.  Anyways, in my life as a carnivore I've never tried a piece of meat that I needed to spit out, let alone gag out.  That a rotten (and by rotten I don't mean "slightly bad" I mean smelled like you shoved your face in a garbage dump)  piece of meat be served in a steakhouse is totally unacceptable.  It was bad enough that the meat was literally a piece of feces, but then they tried to cover it up by acting like it was our problem because we didn't understand their "aging" process. Of course the server smelled it and wouldn't take a bite.

jiMjTgJe4_o3yVbUlH_taA.text: Nice atmosphere pleasant service. I was not impressed. I've had better roast beef and Yorkshire pudding in Chicago.

551LUABMjd7es7sCC_iMqw.text: If you are looking for true traditional British fare this is your place. They are famous for their table carved beef and lamb. We both chose the beef which came with cooked spinach, roasted potatoes and Yorkshire pudding. All were done well but in typical English fashion done without and "flair". The atmosphere was out of a time machine. The pianist played every cliche song imaginable and the decor was 1950 something. I'm not saying it was bad it was just.......... predictable.

e1IPHVob0VVsHwrNiU7ZuA.text: Classic English roast with gravy and Yorkshire pudding carved at your table. Fresh horseradish too.It's the Dickension Sunday dinner. Now truth be told the roast potatoe needs to be improved.The experience does not however. Really a special treat.
